items.title: Snapchat is rolling out AI-powered video lenses
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Snapchat Platinum subscribers can now use AI-powered video lenses featuring animals and flowers.
- Three initial lenses: a fox that snuggles, raccoons that scamper, and flowers that zoom out.
- New lenses will be added weekly, utilizing Snap's generative video model.
- Snap has a history of integrating AR and AI tools into their platform, enhancing user creativity.

items.title: Judge leans towards temporarily saving CFPB amid concerns of dismantling
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- A federal judge may temporarily block plans to dismantle the CFPB, worried about potential impacts on consumer protection.
- Judge Amy Berman Jackson expressed skepticism about the government's claim of stabilizing the CFPB amidst proposed mass layoffs of nearly 1,200 employees.
- Jackson is considering a preliminary injunction to pause terminations while hearing testimony on the agency's future, expected to decide later this month.
- The CFPB is crucial for handling consumer complaints regarding financial institutions and products.
- Concerns raised about the legality of efforts to downsize the agency, with allegations that its acting director is violating separation of powers.
- Witnesses revealed chaotic plans to execute layoffs quickly, raising questions about ability to meet statutory duties, causing a significant backlog of consumer complaints.
- Temporary injunction could allow the CFPB to continue functioning, although not necessarily at full capacity before the court's final decision.

items.title: Samsung launches $10,000 bundle of eight big TVs
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Samsung has introduced a new Buzzer Beater Bundle priced at $10,307.42, featuring eight TVs aimed at college basketball fans.
- The bundle includes a 98-inch 4K Crystal UHD TV, a 65-inch 8K Neo QLED TV, three 65-inch 4K Neo QLED TVs, and three 55-inch 4K QLED TVs. 
- This offer is valid until March 22, 2025, and is marketed as saving customers around $6,000 compared to retail value.

items.title: Sonos cancels plans for streaming video player Pinewood
items.author: Chris Welch
items.summary:
- Sonos has canceled its streaming video player, codenamed Pinewood, initially set for a 2025 launch.
- The decision was announced in an all-hands call and follows extensive beta testing.
- The cancellation leaves Sonos without new significant products for late 2025; the last major release was the Arc Ultra soundbar and Sub 4 in 2024.
- Concerns arose internally about Pinewood replicating past failures to compete in new product categories.

items.title: FCC Chairman Seeks Public Input on Deregulating Agency Regulations
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- FCC Chair Brendan Carr is requesting public input to identify unnecessary regulations for potential removal.
- This initiative follows President Trump's executive orders aimed at deregulation across federal agencies.
- Carr emphasizes the need to eliminate outdated regulatory obstacles that hinder innovators and businesses.
- The public can submit comments on the FCC website for the next 30 days regarding outdated or burdensome regulations.

items.title: A Trump official has been moonlighting as a fashion influencer
items.author: Mia Sato
items.summary:
- McLaurine Pinover, a political appointee in the Trump administration, was also a fashion influencer on Instagram.
- Pinover shared outfit videos and attempted to monetize her content through affiliate links while working at the Office of Personnel Management (OPM).
- Her Instagram account was deleted after CNN contacted her about the story, which raised concerns about using government resources for personal gain.
- Government watchdog groups express that her actions may violate rules against using government resources for private business purposes.

items.title: Moft’s new origami case elevates the iPad for improved ergonomics
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Moft has unveiled the Dynamic Folio case for iPads, designed to enhance ergonomics for users working with Apple Pencil or watching videos.
- The case utilizes an origami design to provide elevation of up to three inches and can support a smartphone simultaneously.
- Available through Kickstarter, the campaign has exceeded its $10,000 goal; prices range from $34 for the Mini size to $55 for the 13-inch version, with shipping starting as early as May 2025.
- Made from a lightweight fiberglass and MOVAS vegan leather, the case weighs 292 grams, lighter than Apple's iPad cases.
- Features include floating modes for different angles and the ability to fold it for portrait or landscape use; an optional holder for Apple Pencil can be added.

items.title: Microsoft isn’t launching its Xbox handheld this year, but Asus might be
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary:
- Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer stated the Xbox handheld is still a prototype and won't launch soon.
- A report suggested an Xbox handheld named Project Keenan in development for a later release, but Microsoft clarifies plans are not solidified yet.
- Asus is involved in producing this handheld, likely debuting later this year, under Microsoft’s broader goal to unify Windows and Xbox.
- The handheld will run Windows but feature an Xbox-like interface, aiming for a universal game library.
- Microsoft is focusing on game preservation and compatibility across platforms, which could reshape the future of Xbox consoles.
- Competing with Valve's SteamOS is also a motive behind these changes, especially given their recent popularity in the handheld market.

items.title: Poker Face season 2 is coming to Peacock this May
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary:
- Season 2 of *Poker Face* is set to premiere on May 8th on Peacock.
- Natasha Lyonne returns as Charlie Cale, solving murder mysteries.
- The new season will include celebrity guest stars like Cynthia Erivo, Katie Holmes, Giancarlo Esposito, Method Man, and John Mulaney.

items.title: Google apologizes for Chromecast outage in email to users
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Google is emailing Chromecast users to apologize for ongoing issues affecting certain models.
- The problems began over the weekend, with devices displaying 'Untrusted device' errors.
- Google is working on a fix and has communicated updates via the [Nest Community page](https://www.googlenestcommunity.com/t5/Streaming/Regarding-an-issue-with-Chromecast-2nd-gen-and-Chromecast-Audio/td-p/686992).
- A Reddit user speculated that the issue may be due to an expired certificate, which became invalid just before the failures began.

items.title: Discovery Plus is finally getting the overhaul it needs
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Discovery Plus is receiving a major upgrade with improved app and video performance through migration to Max's technology.
- The app will feature a refined homepage and navigation along with enhanced content recommendations.
- New features include a QR code login, and users can share show recommendations via text or social media.
- The update is currently rolling out across devices in the US and Canada, expected to take a few days for full deployment.
- This overhaul comes after a recent price increase, making the ad-supported plan $5.99/month and the ad-free plan $9.99/month.

items.title: The travel-friendly Tile Pro has dropped to its best price ever
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary:
- The 2024 Tile Pro is on sale for $24.49, marking a $11 discount and the best price ever.
- It offers a Bluetooth tracking range of 500 feet and a user-replaceable battery.
- The device is compatible with both Android and iOS, making it versatile for various households.
- Users can tap into the Tile Network and Amazon Sidewalk for enhanced tracking capabilities.
- The Tile Pro can double as a panic button for SOS alerts with an optional subscription.

items.title: Updates on Daily Puzzle Games: New Releases and Changes
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Puzzmo is revamping newspaper games, making them more engaging.
- The New York Times has updated its crossword app following its focus on games.
- The 2,500th edition of The New York Times’ Spelling Bee puzzle was released today, featuring a new letter 'S'.
- Samsung's trivia game 'The Six' launches on Galaxy phones after its release on Smart TVs.
- A Strands archive for NYT puzzles was shut down due to a DMCA notice from The New York Times.
- A popular Connections puzzle creator has ceased operations after receiving a cease and desist letter from NYT.
- Words With Friends introduces daily single-player puzzles, similar to Wordle, with multiple formats.
- Daily Sudoku puzzles are set to be added to Apple News Plus in the US with varying difficulty levels.

items.title: Toyota introduces an electric C-HR and updated bZ4X for Europe
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Toyota has introduced an electric version of the C-HR called the C-HR Plus and updated its bZ4X for Europe.
- The C-HR Plus comes with two battery options: a 57.7 kWh battery offering 455 km (283 miles) of range and a 77 kWh battery providing 600 km (373 miles).
- The updated bZ4X uses the same e-TNGA platform, with a long-range version offering a 73.1 kWh battery and ranges of 445 km (276.5 miles) or 573 km (356 miles).
- Changes include battery pre-conditioning for rapid charging in approximately 30 minutes in cold conditions.
- Release set for the second half of the year in Europe, with potential for U.S. announcements later due to favorable sales of the bZ4X.

items.title: Google DeepMind’s new AI models help robots perform physical tasks, even without training
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Google DeepMind launched two new AI models, Gemini Robotics and Gemini Robotics-ER, to enhance robotic capabilities.
- Gemini Robotics can understand and perform real-world tasks without prior training, leveraging advancements in generality, interactivity, and dexterity.
- The model enables robots to perform precise tasks such as folding paper and opening bottles.
- Gemini Robotics-ER is designed for complex reasoning tasks in dynamic environments.
- A safety layer evaluates potential actions to ensure safety during operation.
- Collaboration with partners like Apptronik and Boston Dynamics aims to develop next-gen humanoid robots.

items.title: FCC chair asks if YouTube TV ‘discriminates against faith-based programming’
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- FCC Chairman Brendan Carr questions if YouTube TV discriminates against faith-based channels based on a complaint from Great American Media.
- Carr is exploring the possibility of expanding FCC regulations to include virtual multichannel video programming distributors (MVPDs) like YouTube TV.
- YouTube defends its policies, stating they do not prohibit religious content, and expresses willingness to discuss their negotiation processes with the FCC.
- Google faces additional scrutiny from Rep. Jim Jordan regarding possible censorship at the request of the Biden administration.

items.title: All this bad AI is wrecking a whole generation of gadgets
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- The anticipated boom in gadget innovation due to AI has largely failed to materialize.
- Tech companies have become overly reliant on AI technologies that are not sufficiently developed.
- Apple has been criticized for promoting its products based on AI features that are still incomplete or ineffective.
- Amazon has similarly stalled on new product innovations, focusing on outdated concepts instead.
- Startups are flooding the market with AI-powered gadgets, but many of these products are underwhelming or non-functional.
- There are calls for companies to prioritize practical improvements in hardware instead of waiting for perfect AI solutions.

items.title: Pokémon with guns? All the latest on viral gaming hit Palworld
iRobot tells investors its future is in doubt
I outsourced my memory to an AI pin and all I got was fanfiction
items.author: Victoria Song
items.summary:
- Bee is a $50 AI wearable designed to assist with memory retention by summarizing conversations and sending reminders.
- Users can allow Bee to listen to conversations and summarize significant facts, create to-do lists, and generate daily diary entries.
- The device struggles with accurately interpreting conversations and may produce incorrect summaries or bizarre fanfiction about the user's day.
- The review highlights privacy concerns and potential social awkwardness due to the device's omnipresence in conversations.
- Bee's inaccuracies led to confusion, prompting the reviewer to mute the device in certain situations to respect others' privacy.

items.title: Rivian joins the hands-free highway driving party
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Rivian announces a software update for its second-generation vehicles featuring a [hands-free highway driving](https://stories.rivian.com/enhanced-highway-assist-gen2) capability.
- The feature allows drivers to operate on 135,000 miles of compatible highways in the US and Canada, with plans for expansion in 2026.
- Enhanced Highway Assist manages steering, acceleration, and braking while monitoring driver attention through an infrared camera.
- Future upgrades will introduce a hands-off, eyes-off driving mode for low-speed situations, representing Level 3 automation.
- Rivian also announces a new Rally drive mode and a $5,000 Performance Upgrade unlocking 665 horsepower and new drive modes.

items.title: Pokémon Go developer Niantic to sell gaming business to Saudi group
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Niantic Labs is selling its video game division to Saudi-owned Scopely for $3.5 billion.
- The deal includes Niantic’s titles like Pokémon Go, Monster Hunter Now, and Pikmin Bloom.
- The acquisition requires regulatory approval and will also include social apps Campfire and Wayfarer.
- Pokémon Go attracted over 500 million players in its first year, but faced challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic.
- The deal aligns with Saudi Arabia's investments in the gaming industry through its Public Investment Fund.

items.title: Google is fixing broken incoming images and videos in Messages
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Google Messages is updating to improve media receiving performance.
- Updates address issues with slowdowns and failures in receiving images and videos.
- Users reported problems with RCS, including slow loading, blurry images, and total failures to load attachments.
- Google's community manager stated they are working on a solution and recently rolled out improvements.
- Users are encouraged to provide feedback if issues persist after updates.

items.title: Google calls Gemma 3 the most powerful AI model you can run on one GPU
items.author: Richard Lawler
items.summary:
- Google updates the Gemma AI model family with **Gemma 3**, targeting developers for creating versatile AI applications.
- Claimed to be the **best single-accelerator model** globally, it outperforms **Facebook’s Llama**, **DeepSeek**, and **OpenAI** on a single GPU.
- Introduces an updated vision encoder for high-res images and includes the **ShieldGemma 2** image safety classifier for filtering harmful content.
- Despite advanced capabilities, tests indicate a **low risk** for misuse in creating harmful substances.
- Google is offering **Cloud credits** and a **$10,000 Gemma 3 Academic program** for research.

items.title: From ChatGPT to Gemini: how AI is rewriting the internet
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- AI technology is reshaping online communication and user interaction.
- Google's Gemini model claims to be the leading AI on a single GPU, integrating advanced functionalities and safety classifiers.
- Major tech firms are competing intensely in AI development, with implications for user experience and operational capabilities.
- AI tools are being deployed in various fields including healthcare, where Microsoft's Dragon Copilot is introduced to assist with clinical documentation.

items.title: All the news about Netflix’s gaming efforts
Honey: all the news about PayPal’s alleged scam coupon app
Google changes Chrome extension policies following the Honey link scandal
Everything we know about Apple’s Vision Pro
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Apple Vision Pro is priced at $3,499 and launching in February.
- Preorders details announced on The Vergecast.
- Features a new operating system, visionOS.
- The headset offers an immersive concert experience for Metallica fans.
- New updates improve guest user experience and introduce apps.
- Blackmagic announced its high-quality 3D camera designed for Vision Pro, retailing at $29,995.

items.title: Trump’s first 100 days: all the news affecting the tech industry
Gail Slater is the DOJ’s new antitrust head
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Gail Slater confirmed as the head of the DOJ antitrust division.
- Senate voted with bipartisan support during the confirmation.
- Slater will oversee major antitrust cases, including one against Google.
- She has a long history in antitrust law and previously worked in the Trump administration.
- Slater replaces Jonathan Kanter, amidst ongoing litigation against Google.

items.title: Vergil is out for blood in the latest trailer for Netflix’s Devil May Cry series
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary:
- Netflix released a new trailer for the upcoming adaptation of *Devil May Cry*, debuting on April 3rd.
- The trailer reveals various characters and their intentions against the demon hunter, Dante, voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch.
- Human soldiers, like Lady, see Dante as a threat due to his demonic heritage, adding complexity to the storyline.
- The series will incorporate elements from the *Devil May Cry* games and official manga, promising a richer narrative.

items.title: Is Tesla cooked?
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Tesla stock dropped 15% on Monday, its worst performance in five years.
- Owners are selling their Teslas at significant losses due to dissatisfaction with Elon Musk’s leadership.
- Protests against Tesla and Musk are being organized across the country.
- Tesla has seen a dramatic decline in sales worldwide, with the biggest drops in Europe and China.
- Musk's net worth has decreased by over $100 billion, though he remains the richest person globally.
- The company's vehicle lineup is considered outdated, with recent models failing to capture interest against competitors.
- Tesla's production and delivery figures are flat, raising concerns among investors.
- Musk's focus on high-profile projects like the Cybertruck has overshadowed attempts to develop a more affordable electric vehicle.
- Tesla's image has deteriorated due to Musk’s controversial activities and public statements, leading to vandalism and protests against the brand.
- Uncertainty looms over Tesla's leadership and future direction amid declining sales and growing competition in the EV market.

items.title: Trump says he’ll label attacks on Tesla locations as domestic terrorism
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- President Trump announced he will label violent protests at Tesla locations as domestic terrorism.
- The statement came amid escalating protests against Tesla CEO Elon Musk.
- Recent incidents reported include gunshots and vandalism at Tesla dealerships.
- Trump emphasized that these actions harm a significant American company and stated, "We catch anybody doing it… because they’re harming a great American company."
- A protest group responded, asserting they are a nonviolent grassroots movement and criticized Trump's remarks as an attempt to intimidate them.

items.title: The Best Ebook Reader to Buy Right Now
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary:
- E-readers provide a book-like experience with features such as adjustable front lighting, waterproofing, and note-taking options.
- The Kindle Paperwhite (12th-gen) is recommended for its 7-inch 300ppi display, IPX8 waterproofing, and access to Amazon's ecosystem, priced starting at $159.99.
- The Kobo Libra Colour offers a nice color screen, physical buttons, and supports more file formats but is pricier at $229.99.
- The base-model Kindle is the best cheap option at $109.99, featuring a high-resolution display and USB-C for fast charging.

items.title: iRobot launches eight new Roombas and finally adds lidar mapping
items.author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.summary:
- iRobot announces the launch of eight new Roomba models featuring lidar navigation and mapping.
- Prices range from $299 to $999, with preorders starting on March 18.
- New features include suction power specs, auto-empty docks, and ultrasonic carpet detection.
- Lidar technology provides improved mapping and allows for room-specific cleaning.
- High-end models like the Roomba Plus 505 Combo introduce dual spinning mop pads.
- iRobot’s shift to lidar-based navigation addresses competition from Chinese manufacturers.
- Company aims to simplify product design with a focus on consumer-friendly features such as dust compactors and enhanced mopping capabilities.
- Overall, this launch is seen as a strategic response to market competition, marking a new direction under CEO Gary Cohen.

items.title: Go Read This: The Verge’s favorite reads from all over the web
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- The Verge curates a list of recommended articles and books from various sources.
- Highlights include a controversial EV battery plant proposal by a Chinese company and its implications.
- Other topics cover working outside, gaming industry developments, and the evolving landscape of US politics and technology.

items.title: All the smart home news, reviews, and gadgets you need to know about
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- The smart home offers convenience and safety, but it can also be complex and confusing.
- Verge provides reviews, guides, and news on smart home technologies and gadgets.
- New features and devices for smart homes are frequently released by companies like Apple, Amazon, and Google.
- Abode launched a new app for controlling its security system via Apple TV.
- Ikea registered a Matter-over-Thread temperature sensor called Timmerflotte with the FCC.
- Amazon introduced Alexa Plus, a generative AI-powered voice assistant, aiming to enhance user interaction.

items.title: CFPB official tells judge he’s still not sure if agency will shut down
Judge orders DOGE to release records on an ‘expedited basis’
Davey Wreden's New Game 'Wanderstop' Explores Emotional Depths Through Tea-Making
items.author: Lewis Gordon
items.summary:
- Davey Wreden, known for unconventional games, releases a new title, [Wanderstop](https://youtu.be/TrAJzniyyZI).
- The game features a protagonist named Alta, a fighter in a tea-making fantasy setting, focusing on emotional recovery.
- Wreden seeks to create a game about 'existing in the moment' after experiencing burnout from his previous works.
- Wanderstop combines narrative adventure with cozy farming simulator elements.
- Wreden's trajectory reflects a shift from attention-seeking games to more sincere storytelling.
- The game examines themes of personal demons, mental health, and the limitations of self-care.

items.title: OpenAI launches new tools to help developers build AI agents
Media Matters sues X to stop lawsuits outside of the US
Tesla Cybertruck: all the news about Elon Musk’s futuristic pickup truck
Anker’s compact travel charger works in over 200 countries
A new Pixel 10 leak shows Google adding another camera
BlizzCon is returning in 2026 after a few years off
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- BlizzCon 2026 will take place on September 12th and 13th, 2026, at the Anaheim Convention Center.
- Blizzard has not revealed specific games to be featured but promises an elevated experience with traditional elements like the Opening Ceremony and hands-on gameplay.
- The last BlizzCon occurred in 2023, showcasing new content for Diablo IV and World of Warcraft, among others.

items.title: How longer-lasting, faster-charging batteries are coming via software updates
Google held back Pixel 4A batteries to avoid overheating risk
Monopolies, scalpers, and the future of online ticket sales
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- Ticketmaster faces continued scrutiny and potential antitrust action after a ticketing crisis during Taylor Swift's Eras Tour in 2022.
- Live Nation, which operates Ticketmaster, is accused of monopolistic practices, sparking investigations by the DOJ.
- Legislation is being proposed across many states to regulate ticket sales, aiming to improve consumer experiences and potentially limit Ticketmaster's power.
- The DOJ filed a lawsuit against Live Nation in May 2024, alleging it crushes competition, and criticisms of its business practices are ongoing.
- Resale ticketing remains controversial, with arguments over consumer rights and how it affects ticket prices and accessibility.
- Rival ticketing companies are spending substantially on lobbying to influence legislation that could benefit their interests against Ticketmaster.
